articles.headline: Pope, in U.S., Is ‘Ashamed’ of Pedophile Priests
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI’s comments appeared to soothe many Catholics, but they left others demanding more action.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI’s comments appeared to soothe many Catholics, but they left others demanding more action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Pope Benedict XVI chose to address bluntly the sex scandal that has torn at the church here even before he landed Tuesday on his first official visit to the United States, saying he was “deeply ashamed” by the actions of pedophile priests.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Delta’s Chief Faces Skeptics as He Tries to Sell a Deal With Northwest
articles.snippet: Shares of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines slid following the announcement of the merger and Northwest pilots vowed to kill the $2.7 billion deal.
articles.abstract: Shares of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines slid following the announcement of the merger and Northwest pilots vowed to kill the $2.7 billion deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a conference call with industry analysts on Tuesday, Richard H. Anderson, chief executive of Delta Air Lines, described his just-announced merger plans with Northwest Airlines to create the world’s largest carrier as “a perfect deal.”

articles.headline: Maybe Money Does Buy Happiness After All
articles.snippet: The Easterlin paradox — that economic growth doesn’t necessarily lead to more satisfaction — is under attack.
articles.abstract: The Easterlin paradox — that economic growth doesn’t necessarily lead to more satisfaction — is under attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of World War II, the Japanese economy went through one of the greatest booms the world has ever known. From 1950 to 1970, the economy’s output per person grew more than sevenfold. Japan, in just a few decades, remade itself from a war-torn country into one of the richest nations on earth.

articles.headline: Guild Chief for Actors Is No Pacifist
articles.snippet: Alan Rosenberg said Tuesday he remained angry enough over performer compensation levels to bring the entertainment industry to a halt again.
articles.abstract: Alan Rosenberg said Tuesday he remained angry enough over performer compensation levels to bring the entertainment industry to a halt again.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand why Hollywood is taking the threat of a strike by the Screen Actors Guild seriously, look no further than Alan Rosenberg’s actions during a solidarity march last November with striking screenwriters.

articles.headline: McCain Outlines Broad Proposals for U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: In the clearest view yet of his plans, the senator called for a series of tax cuts and backed away from a pledge to balance the budget by the end of his first term.
articles.abstract: In the clearest view yet of his plans, the senator called for a series of tax cuts and backed away from a pledge to balance the budget by the end of his first term.
articles.lead_paragraph: VILLANOVA, Pa.  Senator John McCain offered the broadest look yet at his economic policies in a speech on Tuesday in Pittsburgh, outlining a series of tax reductions and backing away from his pledge to balance the budget by the end of his first term.

articles.headline: Larger Prey Are Targets of Phishing
articles.snippet: An e-mail scam aimed at the nation’s top executives is raising new alarms about the ease with which people and companies can be deceived by online criminals.
articles.abstract: An e-mail scam aimed at the nation’s top executives is raising new alarms about the ease with which people and companies can be deceived by online criminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  An e-mail scam aimed squarely at the nation’s top executives is raising new alarms about the ease with which people and companies can be deceived by online criminals.

articles.headline: Merck Wrote Drug Studies for Doctors
articles.snippet: Documents unearthed in lawsuits over the pain drug Vioxx provide a rare, detailed look at the industry practice of ghostwriting medical research studies.
articles.abstract: Documents unearthed in lawsuits over the pain drug Vioxx provide a rare, detailed look at the industry practice of ghostwriting medical research studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drug maker Merck drafted dozens of research studies for a best-selling drug, then lined up prestigious doctors to put their names on the reports before publication, according to an article to be published Wednesday in a leading medical journal.

articles.headline: Wall Street Winners Get Billion-Dollar Paydays
articles.snippet: Hedge fund managers are making money on a scale that once seemed unimaginable, even on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Hedge fund managers are making money on a scale that once seemed unimaginable, even on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hedge fund managers, those masters of a secretive, sometimes volatile financial universe, are making money on a scale that once seemed unimaginable, even in Wall Street’s rarefied realms.

articles.headline: Iraqi Unit Flees Post, Despite American’s Plea
articles.snippet: The retreat was a blow to the American effort to push the Iraqis into the lead in the struggle for Sadr City.
articles.abstract: The retreat was a blow to the American effort to push the Iraqis into the lead in the struggle for Sadr City.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A company of Iraqi soldiers abandoned their positions on Tuesday night in Sadr City, defying American soldiers who implored them to hold the line against Shiite militias.

articles.headline: Big Tax Breaks for Businesses in Housing Bill
articles.snippet: Critics say the housing relief bill is adding up to a bailout for businesses, as the legislation includes billions of dollars in tax breaks for automakers and airlines.
articles.abstract: Critics say the housing relief bill is adding up to a bailout for businesses, as the legislation includes billions of dollars in tax breaks for automakers and airlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate proclaimed a fierce bipartisan resolve two weeks ago to help American homeowners in danger of foreclosure. But while a bill that senators approved last week would take modest steps toward that goal, it would also provide billions of dollars in tax breaks  for automakers, airlines, alternative energy producers and other struggling industries, as well as home builders.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and David M. Herszenhorn
